State of UX

item.title: Accessibility
item.description: [!tldr] Accessibility Ensure that your website is available to everyone. Allowing your pages to respond to different screen sizes is just one way of making sure your website is accessible to as many people as possible.

item.title: Design base
item.description: Overview name frequently used features note Glance Thumbnail of site1 Thumbnail of site2 Thumbnail of site3 Thumbnail of site4 Title with Link Title with Link Title with Link Title with Link

item.title: Graphic design assistances
item.description: Overview name frequently used features note more.graphics Hexagon pattern, Gradient, Geometric Illustration link Select and use appropriate service for your task.

item.title: Icons
item.description: [!tldr] Icons Use SVG for scalable responsive iconography. Most images are part of your content, but icons are part of your user interface.

item.title: Interaction
item.description: [!tldr] Interaction Prepare your pages for different input mechanism; mouse, keyboard, and touch. Small screen devices like mobile phones often have touchscreens.

item.title: Internationalization
item.description: [!tldr] Internationalization Prepare your designs for different languages and writing modes. The World Wide Web is available to everyone in the worldâ€”it’s right there in the name!

item.title: Introduction
item.description: [!tldr] Introduction Find out where responsive design came from. Right from the start, the World Wide Web was designed to be agnostic.

item.title: Macro layouts
item.description: [!tldr] Macro layouts Design page layouts using a choice of CSS techniques. Macro layouts describe the larger, page-wide organization of your interface.

item.title: Media features
item.description: [!tldr] Media features A round-up of all the ways that media features let you respond to devices and preferences.

item.title: Media queries
item.description: [!tldr] Media queries Adapt your designs to different screen sizes using CSS media queries. Designers can adjust their designs to accommodate users.

item.title: Micro layouts
item.description: [!tldr] Micro layouts Build flexible components that can be placed anywhere When we think of layouts, we often think of page-level designs.

item.title: Responsive images
item.description: [!tldr] Responsive images Give your visitors the most appropriate images for their devices and screens. Text on the web automatically wraps at the edge of the screen so that it doesn’t overflow.

item.title: Screen configurations
item.description: [!tldr] Screen configurations Prepaare your content for devices with multiple screens. Responsive web design was in many ways a reaction to mobile phones.

item.title: The picture element
item.description: [!tldr] The picture element Exercise more creative control over your images. The previous module demonstrated how the srcset attribute allows you to provide different-sized versions of the same image.

item.title: Theming
item.description: [!tldr] Theming Adapt your design to match user preferences such as a dark mode. Even branding can be responsive.

item.title: Typography
item.description: [!tldr] Typography Make your text legible and beautiful, no matter where it appears. If you don’t specify any styles for your text, browsers will apply their own default styles.

item.title: User interface patterns
item.description: [!tldr] User interface patterns Consider some scommon UI elements that adopt to differenet screen sizes. A design viewed on a small screen shouldn’t look like a shrunk-down version of a large-screen layout.

item.title: Web assets
item.description: Overview Name Frequently used features Note Font awesome use a kit, javascript API Fontpair figma plugin, chrome extension â­â­â­â­â­ ì‚°ëŒêµ¬ë¦„ ì´ë¯¸ì§€ë¡œ í°íŠ¸ ê²€ìƒ‰ ì´ë¯¸ì§€ë¥¼ ì—…ë¡œë“œí•˜ì—¬ ì›í•˜ëŠ” ì˜ì—­ ì§€ì • adobe font ì›¹ì‚¬ì´íŠ¸ ë‚´ ê¸°ëŠ¥ ì´ìš© Glance Fontawesome Fontpiar ì‚°ëŒêµ¬ë¦„ ì´ë¯¸ì§€ë¡œ í°íŠ¸ ê²€ìƒ‰ adobe font
